Explanation: Long URLs are often used to obfuscate phishing attempts.
URL shorteners can hide the true destination (phishing tactic).
Multiple '//' in URL path may indicate redirection tricks.
Hyphens in domain names are more common in phishing sites.
Excessive subdomains can mimic legitimate domains.
'https' in the path/query may be used to appear secure.
Checks if SSL/TLS is valid (phishing sites may lack it).
Short-lived domains are often used for phishing.
External favicons may indicate phishing.
Many dots in the URL can indicate obfuscation.
Suspicious characters (?, %, &, =, +) are often used in phishing URLs.
Use of scripts can be used for malicious purposes.
Many third-party domains can be suspicious.
Meta tags can be abused for phishing.
High ratio of external scripts may be suspicious.
Phishing sites often use forms to steal data.
'mailto:' links can be used for phishing.
Forwarding can hide the real destination.
Custom status bars can hide true links.
Popups are often used in phishing.
Iframes can be used to load malicious content.
Sensitive forms are a phishing indicator.
Young domains are more likely to be phishing.
Low DNS record count can indicate a suspicious site.
Suspicious WHOIS info can indicate phishing.
